Issues.Title: ComboBox Binding Sequence Affecting Binding Ability of Other Controls
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

 7.0.302

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

_No response_

### Issue description

The binding ability of the CheckBox control is affected by the sequence of ComboBox binding. If the ComboBox is binded first, the subsequent binding will not work.

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/97237245/d355b199-8fb3-4df2-8ee4-11b9f99c06cf



### Steps to reproduce

1. Open the sln file and run the WinformApp. [Binding Sequence Issue.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/11716905/Binding.Sequence.Issue.zip)
2. Click on Button, go to tabPage2.
3. Toggle the Checkbox and to change the visibility of the Label in the GroupBox. Note that the checkbox is working as intended.
4. Open the UserControl2.cs file.
5. Go to Line 35 and move the BindComboBox line above of the two other bindings.
6. Run the program again by repeating step 1-3.
7. Note that the toggling of CheckBox is no longer working, where the Label is invisible regardlessly.

Note that when the GroupBox (containing the Label) and CheckBox is in tabPage1 instead of tabPage2 , the ComboBox binding sequence wonâ€™t affect the functionality of the CheckBox

1. Go to Line 79 & 80 in UserControl2.Designer.cs.
2. Replace the tabPage2 of groupBox and checkBox with tabPage1.
3. Launch the program and the checkbox is working fine.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ComboBox Binding Sequence Affecting Binding Ability of Other Controls" (#9272)

Issues.Title: A11y_.NET Core_WinForms_PrintingTesting_PrintingTesting_ScreenReader: Narrator is not announcing the content inside the pane which is present below "View your page" label.
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

Microsoft.Net SDK6.0.311 (x64)

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No Response

### Issue description

### GitHubTags:
#A11yMAS;#A11yTCS;#BM_.NET Core[Winforms]-Win32-May2023;#.NET Core;#A11ySev2;#WCAG1.3.1;#DesktopApp;#Win11;#NonBenchmark;#Narrator;#Nvda

### Actual:
Narrator is not announcing the content inside the pane which is present below "View your page" label.

### Expected:
Narrator should announce the content inside the pane which is present below "View your page" label.

### User Impact:
Screen reader users will get confused & will not understand if narrator does not announce the content inside the pane which is present below "View your page" label.

### Attachment:

Narrator:
![SR](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/125462007/e34ef8fe-def5-4f55-b851-9c033bd9ac40)

NVDA:
![SR2](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/125462007/38b758dd-0a30-4f3a-a543-f3f4f64a1215)


### Steps to reproduce

1. Install and Open "Winforms" App.
2. "Main Form" screen would appear.
3. TAB to "Printing_Controls:Testing the controls under the Printings Tab" and press ENTER key.
4. "Printing Testing" screen appears.
5. Start Narrator.
6. Now observe that Narrator is not announcing the content inside the pane which is present below "View your page" label.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "A11y_.NET Core_WinForms_PrintingTesting_PrintingTesting_ScreenReader: Narrator is not announcing the content inside the pane which is present below "View your page" label." (#9271)

Issues.Title: A11y_.NET Core_WinForms_Print_Microsoft Print to PDF Advanced Options_ScreenReader: Narrator focus is not going to the combo box which is present beside "Paper Size" & "Copy count"
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

Microsoft.Net SDK6.0.311 (x64)

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No response

### Issue description

### GitHubTags:
#A11yMAS;#A11yTCS;#BM_.NET Core[Winforms]-Win32-May2023;#.NET Core;#A11ySev3;#WCAG2.4.3;#DesktopApp;#Win11;#NonBenchmark;#Narrator;#Nvda

### Actual:
Narrator focus is not going to the combo box which is present beside "Paper Size" & "Copy count" tree view.

### NOTE: Issue is not observed with NVDA.

### Expected:
Narrator focus should go to the combo box which is present beside "Paper Size" & "Copy count" tree view.

### User Impact:
Screen reader users will face difficulty to understand & will not get correct information of the "Paper Size" & "Copy count" combo box which is present in the tree view.

### Attachment:
Narrator:
![ComboBox](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/125462007/d3e753d6-bb5e-4574-9538-3194a75e3b29)

NVDA:
![ComboBox2](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/125462007/0cbeca50-c353-412c-a231-8efbefac9540)


### Steps to reproduce

1. Install and Open "Winforms" App.
2. "Main Form" screen would appear.
3. TAB to "Printing_Controls:Testing the controls under the Printings Tab" and press ENTER key.
4. "Printing Testing" screen appears.
5. TAB to "Print" tab and press ENTER key .
6. "Printing from win 32 application" screen appears.
7. TAB to "Show more settings" and press ENTER key.
8. "Printing Preference" screen appears.
9. TAB to "Advanced" button and press ENTER key.
10. "Microsoft print to PDF advanced options" screen appears.
11. Start Narrator.
12. Now observe that Narrator focus is not going to the combo box which is present beside "Paper Size" & "Copy count" tree view.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "A11y_.NET Core_WinForms_Print_Microsoft Print to PDF Advanced Options_ScreenReader: Narrator focus is not going to the combo box which is present beside "Paper Size" & "Copy count"" (#9270)

Issues.Title: A11y_.NET Core_WinForms_PrintingTesting_Setting_ScreenReader: Narrator is not announcing label "Paper" when navigating to the combo box and also for "Orientation" & "Margins (millimeters)".
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

Microsoft.Net SDK6.0.311 (x64)

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No response

### Issue description

### GitHubTags:
#A11yMAS;#A11yTCS;#BM_.NET Core[Winforms]-Win32-May2023;#.NET Core;#A11ySev3;#WCAG1.3.1;#DesktopApp;#Win11;#NonBenchmark;#Narrator;#Nvda

### Actual:
Narrator is not announcing label "Paper" when navigating to the "Size" combo box and also for "Portrait" "Landscape" "Radio buttons" it is not announcing label "Orentation".

### NOTE: Issue is not observed with NVDA.

### Expected:
Narrator should announce the label "Paper" when navigating to the "Size" combo box and also for "Portrait" "Landscape" "Radio buttons" it should announce the label "Orentation".

### User Impact:
Screen reader users will get confused with narrator does not announce the label along with text.

### Attachment:
Narrator:
![ScreenReader](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/125462007/cb0a896b-a007-488d-9200-e6f87751cc14)

NVDA:
![ScreenReader2](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/125462007/b92177d8-96e2-4564-9012-579ab4c5a338)


### Steps to reproduce

1. Install and Open "Winforms" App.
2. "Main Form" screen would appear.
3. TAB to "Printing_Controls:Testing the controls under the Printings Tab" and press ENTER key.
4. "Printing Testing" screen appears.
5. TAB to "Settings" tab and press ENTER key.
6. "Page Setup" screen appears.
7. Start Narrator.
8. Now observe that narrator is not announcing the labels names for "Size" combo box & "Portrait" "Landscape" "Radio buttons".
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "A11y_.NET Core_WinForms_PrintingTesting_Setting_ScreenReader: Narrator is not announcing label "Paper" when navigating to the combo box and also for "Orientation" & "Margins (millimeters)"." (#9269)

Issues.Title: A11y_.NET Core_WinForms_Winforms_Containers_SplitContainer_SetBackColor_Keyboard: After pressing ENTER on the "Windows_Containers" Keyboard focus is not visible on the "button15" which is present below "SplitContainer_SetBlackColor_Panel1_Green_Panel2_Red".
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

Microsoft.Net SDK6.0.311 (x64)

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No response

### Issue description

### GitHubTags:
#A11yMAS;#A11yTCS;#BM_.NET Core[Winforms]-Win32-May2023;#.NET Core;#A11ySev3;#WCAG2.4.7;#DesktopApp;#Win11;#NonBenchmark;#Keyboard

### Actual:
After pressing ENTER on the "Windows_Containers" Keyboard focus is not visible on the "button15" which is present below "SplitContainer_SetBlackColor_Panel1_Green_Panel2_Red".

### Expected:
After pressing ENTER on the "Windows_Containers" Keyboard focus should be visible on the "button15" which is present below "SplitContainer_SetBlackColor_Panel1_Green_Panel2_Red".

### User Impact:
Keyboard users will not be able to understand which control has the keyboard focus after pressing ENTER on the "Windows_Containers".

### Attachments:
![Focusvisible](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/125462007/92dc1667-3200-4c21-8e39-340f78d2a4c7)


### Steps to reproduce

1. Install and Open "Winforms" App.
2. "Main Form" screen would appear.
3. TAB to "Container_Control_2: Testing the Control under the Containers tab" and press ENTER key.
4. Now observe that after pressing ENTER key on the "Container_Control_2: Testing the Control under the Containers tab"   keyboard focus is not visible on the "button15" which is present below "SplitContainer_SetBlackColor_Panel1_Green_Panel2_Red".
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "A11y_.NET Core_WinForms_Winforms_Containers_SplitContainer_SetBackColor_Keyboard: After pressing ENTER on the "Windows_Containers" Keyboard focus is not visible on the "button15" which is present below "SplitContainer_SetBlackColor_Panel1_Green_Panel2_Red"." (#9260)

Issues.Title: A11y_.NET Core_WinForms_Remaining_Controls_Testing_Remaining Controls_Non-Text Contrast: Color contrast ratio of the "Track slider" is 1.53:1 which is less than 3:1.
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

Microsoft.Net SDK6.0.311 (x64)

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No response

### Issue description

### GitHubTags:
#A11yMAS;#A11yTCS;#BM_.NET Core[Winforms]-Win32-May2023;#.NET Core;#A11ySev2;#WCAG1.4.11;#DesktopApp;#Win11;#NonBenchmark;#Non-TextContrast

### Actual:
Color contrast ratio of the "Track slider" is 1.53:1 which is less than 3:1 which is present beside "Settings for DomainupDown".

### Expected:
Color contrast ratio of the "Track slider" should be more or equal to 3:1 which is present beside "Settings for DomainupDown".

### User Impact:
Low vision users will face difficulty if the color contrast ratio of the "Track Slider" is less than 3:1.

### Attachments:
![NonTextContrast](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/125462007/a7cf90ef-44ca-46d7-b5c0-2d54dd8b2346)


### Steps to reproduce

1. Install and Open "Winforms" App.
2. "Main Form" screen would appear.
3. TAB to "Remaining_Controls_Testing" and press ENTER key.
4. TAB to "Track Slider".
5. Open "Accessibility Insights for Windows".
6. Now observe that Color contrast ratio of the "Track slider" is 1.53:1 which is less than 3:1 which is present beside "Settings for DomainupDown".
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "A11y_.NET Core_WinForms_Remaining_Controls_Testing_Remaining Controls_Non-Text Contrast: Color contrast ratio of the "Track slider" is 1.53:1 which is less than 3:1." (#9259)

Issues.Title: ContextMenuStrip doesn't scale well for its menu item's checked icon.
Issues.Body:
### Environment

Visual Studio 2022 17.2.6

### .NET version

.NET6.0

### Did this work in a previous version of Visual Studio and/or previous .NET release?

have not tested any previous version

### Issue description

200% dpi, 4k screen
a demo, only have two controls: ContextMenuStrip and MenuStrip, add random menuitem for them.
The issue is that the vertical panel is too narrow for the checked icon in ContextMenuStrip, as a contrast, the MenuStrip is normal.
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/6090982/b6754651-3284-43cd-9d19-322407b63b12)
![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/6090982/732d296a-cc48-447d-a636-9020d121f656)



### Steps to reproduce

1. create a WinForm app.
2. add a ContextMenuStrip control and a MenuStrip control from toolbox
3. add some menu item for them
4. set check state of one menu item to true
5. run app

### Diagnostics

_No response_
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ContextMenuStrip doesn't scale well for its menu item's checked icon." (#9258)

Issues.Title: Update COM type descriptor extended browsing handlers
Issues.Body:
This cleans up the COM type descriptor extended property handlers for supported property interfaces.

- Uses interfaces directly, enabling ComWrapper scenarios
- Simplifies the handler instance handling - no longer uses Activator.CreateInstance
- Bring variable names up to standard (notably for event args)
- Add simple supports interface helper in ComHelpers
- Add interface for COM2ExtendedBrowsingHandler and make base class generic of interface type

Additional PRs will follow that change away from casting to managed COM interfaces to suppport AOT / ComWrappers.

Issues.Title: Update control owning field of Label and Panel to using weak references
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

Related to #9224 


## Proposed changes

- Update the control owning field of Label and Panel to using weak references
- Enable the GC collect test for the Label and Panel control in unit test cases

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- The strong reference used by the original Owner property can cause a memory leak

## Regression? 

- No

- Unit tests

Issues.Title: [Accessibility] Narrator cannot announce the indeterminate state of DataGridViewCheckBoxCell correctly
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET SDK 8.0.100-preview.4.23260.5

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No

### Issue description

When set DataGridViewCheckBoxCell  value to Indeterminate, Narrator cannot announce that state is Indeterminate, but "Unchecked".

![DataGridViewCeckBoxCell - indeterminate announced as unchecked in 8 0](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/113603457/bb8e6551-8967-43ab-994e-022ca9b914ad)

![DataGridViewCeckBoxCell - indeterminate is Off in 8 0](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/113603457/9d124cd1-5a86-49d4-994d-46b933d0ec81)


### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a Winforms .Net Core application with DataGridView.
2. Add a DataGridViewCheckBoxColumn to DataGridView.
3. Build and run application.
4. Launch Narrator to focus on a grid check box cell.

Sample app:  [WinFormsApp1.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/11688232/WinFormsApp1.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Accessibility] Narrator cannot announce the indeterminate state of DataGridViewCheckBoxCell correctly" (#9256)

Issues.Title: A11y_.NET Core_WinForms_PrintTesting_Print_ColorContrast: Color contrast ratio is less than 4.5:1 for the "Stores printing output to a file" text where the ratio is 3.278:1
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

Microsoft.Net SDK6.0.311 (x64)

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No response

### Issue description

### GitHubTags:
#A11yMAS;#A11yTCS;#BM_.NET Core[Winforms]-Win32-May2023;#.NET Core;#A11ySev2;#WCAG1.4.3;#DesktopApp;#Win11;#NonBenchmark;#ColorContrast

### Actual:
Color contrast ratio for "Stores printing output to a file" text 3.278:1 which is present below "Print to a file" where the ratio is less than 4.5:1.

### Expected:
Color contrast ratio for "Stores printing output to a file" text 3.278:1 which is present below "Print to a file" where the ratio should be greater than or equal to 4.5:1.

### User Impact:
Low vision users find it difficult to see the text if the color contrast ratio is less than 4.5:1.

### Attachment:
![Color Contrast](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/125462007/6f9611f9-ca1d-4e8e-9951-2146bbd579e8)


### Steps to reproduce

1. Install and Open "Winforms" App.
2. "Main Form" screen would appear.
3. TAB to "Printing_Controls:Testing the controls under Printing Tab" and press ENTER key.
4. TAB to "Print' button and press ENTER key.
5. Now "Printing from win32 application - Print" appears on the screen.
6. TAB to "Store Printing output to a file".
7.Open Accessibility Insights for Windows.
8.Now observe the issue that Color contrast ratio for "Stores printing output to a file" text 3.278:1 which is present below "Print to a file" where the ratio is less than 4.5:1.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "A11y_.NET Core_WinForms_PrintTesting_Print_ColorContrast: Color contrast ratio is less than 4.5:1 for the "Stores printing output to a file" text where the ratio is 3.278:1" (#9248)

Issues.Title: A11y_.NET Core_WinForms_Print_Microsoft Print to PDF Advanced Options_Keyboard: Keyboard focus is going to text i.e., "Paper size" "Copy count" which is present below "Paper/Output" tree view after press ENTER key the dialog is getting closed.
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

Microsoft.Net SDK6.0.311 (x64)

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No response

### Issue description

### GitHubTags:
#A11yMAS;#A11yTCS;#BM_.NET Core[Winforms]-Win32-May2023;#.NET Core;#A11ySev2;#WCAG2.1.1#DesktopApp;#Win11;#NonBenchmark;#Keyboard

### Actual:
Keyboard focus is going to text i.e., "Paper size" "Copy count" which is present below "Paper/Output" tree view after press ENTER key the dialog is automatically getting closed.

### Expected:
Keyboard focus is going to text i.e., "Paper size" "Copy count" which is present below "Paper/Output" tree view after press ENTER key the dialog should not get automatically closed.

### User Impact:
Keyboard only users will face difficulties and gets confused if the dialog gets automatically closed after pressing ENTER key.

### Attachment:
![keyboard focus](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/125462007/39d8901b-f724-47a4-a554-044c521e990b)


### Steps to reproduce

1. Install and Open "Winforms" App.
2. "Main Form" screen would appear.
3. TAB to "Printing_Controls:Testing the controls under Printing Tab" and press ENTER key.
4. TAB to "Print' button and press ENTER key.
5. Now "Printing from win32 application - Print" appears on the screen.
6. TAB to "More Settings" button and press ENTER key.
7. Now "Printing Preference" Screen will appear.
8. TAB to "Advanced" button and press ENTER key.
9. Now "Microsoft print to PDF Advanced Options" screen will appear.
10.Now observe that Keyboard focus is going to text i.e., "Paper size" "Copy count" which is present below "Paper/Output" tree view after press ENTER key the dialog is automatically getting closed.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "A11y_.NET Core_WinForms_Print_Microsoft Print to PDF Advanced Options_Keyboard: Keyboard focus is going to text i.e., "Paper size" "Copy count" which is present below "Paper/Output" tree view after press ENTER key the dialog is getting closed." (#9252)

Issues.Title: [Multi-Monitor] ThreadExceptionDialog doesn't scaled well when DPI is differ
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET 8.0.100-preview.6.23307.24

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No, the result on the latest 8.0 is different from .Net 7.0

### Issue description

ThreadExceptionDialog doesn't scaled well when application is in PerMonitorV2 mode and DPI is differ
The result on the latest 8.0 is different from .Net 7.0, but all aren't scaled well.

**.Net 8.0: from 100% primary monitor to 300% secondary monitor**

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/26474449/637fdfdb-49a7-4e57-9a04-e5b30d032cdb

**.Net 8.0: from 300% primary monitor to 100% secondary monitor**

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/26474449/f952cdb4-8467-41cd-83dd-179167fc21bd

**.Net 7.0: from 100% primary monitor to 300% secondary monitor**

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/26474449/1eb1296b-2cd5-482a-8349-4b61659361bb

**.Net 7.0: from 300% primary monitor to 100% secondary monitor**

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/26474449/597b6b79-523e-4e9f-9b88-0cad43de322c



### Steps to reproduce

**Repro steps:**
1. Create a Winforms .Net Core application with a button
2. Double click button to generate event
3. In the event, add following code to show ThreadException dialog
```
private void button1_Click(object sender, EventArgs e)
{
    using ThreadExceptionDialog dialog = new(new Exception("Really long exception description string, because we want to see if it properly wraps around or is truncated."));
    dialog.ShowDialog(this);
}
```
4. Do some testing between 2 different monitors

**Test application:** 
[WinFormsApp6.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/11685438/WinFormsApp6.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Multi-Monitor] ThreadExceptionDialog doesn't scaled well when DPI is differ" (#9251)

Issues.Title: [Multi-Monitor] PictureBox don't scale well on the secondary monitor when application is in PerMonitorV2 mode
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET 8.0.100-preview.6.23307.24

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No, it doesn't work in .NET 6.0/7.0/8.0, not a regression issue.

### Issue description

Testapp: [testpictureboxapp.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/11685082/testpictureboxapp.zip)

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/86937911/a1d2f5d6-accc-4e20-9ca2-236d2bdc0eb3

100%DPI:

![picturebox100](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/86937911/218455b2-df12-4c55-8bcf-ea7f8d6c2e07)

100% primary monitor -> 300% secondary monitor:

![picturebox300](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/86937911/cfefd915-4d20-453a-b240-890bb91157e0)

This issue also repro's when move from 300% primary monitor to 100% secondary monitor.

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/86937911/84d21b90-ceea-4282-9794-7f1ce1acee36

This issue also repro's on design time.

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/86937911/47a42df1-b8ed-4a4d-80db-622c3b32f05a



### Steps to reproduce

1. Launch VS instance on 100% primary monitor.
2. Add `<ApplicationHighDpiMode>PerMonitorV2</ApplicationHighDpiMode>` in csproj file.
3. Close and reopen Solution.
4. Add an PictureBox with images to form designer.
5. Build and run the application.
6. Move to 300% secondary monitor.

**More Info:**

1. This issue also repro's on design time.
2. This issue also repro's when move from 300% primary monitor to 100% secondary monitor.
3. This issue only repro on `PerMonitorV2`application mode.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Multi-Monitor] PictureBox don't scale well on the secondary monitor when application is in PerMonitorV2 mode " (#9249)

Issues.Title: [Accessibility] Narrator cannot announce the indeterminate state of CheckedListBox item correctly
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET SDK 8.0.100-preview.4.23260.5

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Yes, it is a regression issue, cannot repro in .Net 5, and repro in .Net 6, 7 versions

### Issue description

CheckedListBox item's state can be set to **Indeterminate** programmatically:

```
checkedListBox1.SetItemCheckState(2, CheckState.Indeterminate);
```


Narrator announces **Indeterminate** state as **Checked**.

#### .NET 8.0:
![CheckedListBox - indeterminate state annouced as checked in 8 0](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/113603457/17beb2a1-bd9c-43d7-bb54-9c6e2c1d63f5)
![CheckedListBox - indeterminate state as On in 8 0](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/113603457/4cb60f37-83a3-4aec-ad15-8352f72163e0)

#### .NET 5.0:
![CheckedListBox - indeterminate state annouced correctly in 5 0](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/113603457/3d2b8fda-6e11-46f5-936b-d1c87eae65ac)
![CheckedListBox - indeterminate state is correct in 5 0](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/113603457/e394ca15-fb00-4a06-a92b-52681b00b70e)


### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a Winforms .Net Core application with CheckedListBox.
2. Call `SetItemCheckState` method for one of CheckedListBox items.
3. Build and run application.
4. Launch Narrator to focus on that item.

Sample app:  [WinFormsApp1.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/11679033/WinFormsApp1.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Accessibility] Narrator cannot announce the indeterminate state of CheckedListBox item correctly" (#9243)
